question_text: Quantitatively, how does the ion exchange capacity (IEC) of sulphonated resins correlate with FFA conversion in biodiesel production, and what are the trade-offs with surface area and pore structure?
standard_answer: Ion exchange capacity (IEC), measured in mmol H⁺/g, directly correlates with FFA conversion up to a point, but trade-offs with surface area and pore structure dictate optimal performance. Higher IEC provides more acid sites for proton donation, accelerating the esterification reaction rate according to kinetic models where rate ∝ [H⁺]. For instance, resins with IEC ~5 mmol/g (e.g., Amberlyst 15) achieve ~96% conversion under ideal conditions. However, excessive functionalization can reduce accessible surface area by blocking micropores, as seen in hyper-crosslinked resins where higher sulphonation decreased BET area from 280 to 205 m²/g, lowering efficiency. Pore structure also modulates mass transfer; macroporous resins with large pore diameters (>50 nm) facilitate FFA diffusion to acid sites, enhancing conversion despite moderate IEC. The paper states: 'conversions increased linearly with the resins hydrogen exchange capacity, pointing out the key role of this parameter,' but also notes that 'a greater extent of functionalization reduces the available surface area, likely because (solvated) acid groups blocks some of the network micropores.' Thus, an optimal catalyst balances high IEC with sufficient surface area and pore volume to ensure reactant accessibility, avoiding diffusion limitations that cap conversion gains.
